page.title: 06Birds in our area
page.content: A group of children carried out a bird survey in the locale of Aston Rowant, Kingston Blount and Chinnor.They lie between the Upper and Lower Icknield Ways,along the spring line at the floor of the Chiltern Hills.The land is agricutural,mainly arable,with some grazing.The gardens around the villages the thick hedges along the tracks and the adjacent,disused railway line, provide a rich area both for breeding species and for winter migrants which feed on the lush selection of berries. Birds breeding in the mature,beech woodlands on the Chiltern escarpment, such as green and greater spotted woodpeckers,visit the area mainly in the winter,although the lesser spotted woodpecker is a rare visitor since Dutch Elm disease decimated the elms. The number of sparrowhawks has increased since DDT was banned.
